title: Dropdown
summary: A dropdown enables the user to choose one or multiple options from a list.
preamble: The dropdown component is designed for single or multiple selections but with customizable features.
anatomy-overview:
The dropdown (and other form controls) are divided in sections that are re-used between components.

*   **Header**: Label, label support, contextual help, extended support.
    
*   **Body**: The field with leading and trailing slots.
    
*   **Footer**: Error message.
compare-content: Highly customizable, with support for single or multiple selections, and custom option layouts. Can also act as a combobox, allowing users to enter text directly or choose an option.

columns.content:
*   **Large**
    
*   **Small**: Used in tables and in certain cases where space is very limited. (Custom layouts are not supported.)

columns.title: Label
columns.content: All dropdown fields must have a label to ensure clarity and accessibility. Labels help users understand the purpose of the field, including those using assistive technologies.

columns.title: Optional field indicator
columns.content: We only ask for required information. If some fields are optional, we let users know by adding "(optional)" in brackets next to the field label. The word "(optional)" is shown in regular font weight to distinguish it from the label.

columns.title: Support text
columns.content: Use this to explain how to fill in the field, for example how to count or what to include.

overview.title: Contextual help
overview.section-content:
If the label and support text aren’t enough to explain a field, we can use the info icon. Clicking the icon shows additional support text between the label support and the field.

*   Use a tooltip if space is limited.
    
*   Use a modal for large amounts of text.

columns.caption: Use the info icon to show more support text.

columns.title: Leading icon
columns.content: A leading icon visually reinforces the purpose of the field, helping users to understand what type of information is needed.

columns.caption: Leading icon to distinguish the field.

overview.title: Single select
overview.section-content: Use this version when users should select only one option from the list.

columns.caption: Single select dropdown with one option selected.

overview.title: Multi select
overview.section-content: Use this version when users should be able to select one or multiple options from the list.

columns.caption: Multi select dropdown, three options selected.

overview.title: Search
overview.section-content:
A search field can be used to filter the options.

*   If the list is long (e.g., 10+ items), searching helps users find what they need faster.
    
*   When items are similar or not in a predictable order, searching improves efficiency.
    
*   If users have a specific item in mind, typing is often faster than scrolling.
    
*   Search helps users who navigate with keyboards or screen readers find options more quickly.

overview.title: Option groups
overview.section-content: If the options can be grouped, this helps users find choices in large lists. The group can include a badge showing the number of options it contains.

overview.title: Custom option layout
overview.section-content: The text slot for each dropdown and option supports a custom layout with multiple values, typically used for account selection. These layouts can be customised for specific use cases. Note that these fields are taller than a regular dropdown.

columns.title: Combo box
columns.content: This field allows users to type directly into it, like a standard input field. As they type, a list of matching options appears. If they enter an option that isn’t in the list, it is still accepted as a valid choice.

columns.title: Clearable
columns.content: To make it easy for users to clear a field, an x-icon button can be placed at the end of the field. This is commonly used in search/filter forms.

columns.caption: Makes it easy to clear a field.

columns.title: Error message
columns.content: Used to indicate that a selection must be made from the dropdown or that there is an error with the selected option.

ux-text.title: Writing UX text for drop-downs
ux-text.section-content:
### Labels

The same writing principles apply to labels for input fields, drop-downs, radio buttons, checkboxes, headings, page titles, navigation links, and other short texts.

When selection components follow common design standards, users understand how to use them and submit their choices. You don’t need to add words like Select in drop-downs they already know what to do.

ux-text.title: Use clear and informative words
ux-text.section-content: Texts should be clear and to the point. Explain exactly what information is needed.

columns.title: Single words or full sentences
columns.content:
Keep texts as short as possible. Labels can be single words or full sentences. In some cases, questions work best to prompt users for the right details, such as:

*   What type of property is it?
    
*   How many adults will live in the new home?
    
*   How do you earn your main income?

columns.title: Multiple selections
columns.content: If users can choose multiple options in a dropdown, clarify this in the label or description. Drop-down choices should be short and easy to understand.

ux-text.title: Placeholder text
ux-text.section-content: If a drop-down has no default option, the placeholder text should say Select.

ux-text.title: Capitalisation rules
ux-text.section-content:
Headings and labels should not have every word capitalised. Use capital letters only for:

*   The first letter of the first word
    
*   Proper names
    
*   Abbreviations

accessibility.section-content: All values we measure need to pass in order to give a check on the accessibility on all our components.

columns.title: Keyboard navigation
columns.content: Uses default navigation: Tabs as normal and trigger on key-up with space and on key-down with enter and selecting options with arrow up and down.
